content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one!

Here is my solution in Python:

d={}
k=[]
s=' passes the ball to '
for i in range(int(input())):
    a,b=input().split(s)
    k+=[a]
    d[b]=a

for i in k:print(f'{i}{s}{d[i]}')

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was a fun, realistic problem with a fairly easy solution. I think the obscure characters in the test cases aren't necessary and hopefully don't disadvantage certain languages.
Also I would put "i.e. each line of output should start with the same name as the corresponding line of input." in <<bold>> just to make that part very clear (I thought that was the hardest part of the problem).

I found it difficult to understand what "in the same order as input" meant for the output. It was never clarified that rules could be out of order and that made it difficult to problem solve as the only time that came into account was in the long name test and afterwards. This made it nearly impossible to debug as I could never read a single line of input on one screen, I would constantly need to scroll back and forth. I'd be happy to approve this, but the statement needs to be more clear. And more succinct tests. Usually subsequent tests only add one extra level of complexity, but several of yours add multiple at once, making it difficult to discern why a test might fail.

> "It was never clarified that rules could be out of order"

What exactly do you mean by this? That you expected the rule for person X be adjecant to the rule for whomever X is passing the ball to? The fact that the first 2 test cases have that order is an unfortunate side effect of having test cases with N <= 3. 

I added a clarification to the output section. Do you have any better recommendation on how to specify more clearly that each line of output should start with the same name as the corresponding line in the input?

> "subsequent tests only add one extra level of complexity"

I agree that this should be the case. I added more cases and ordered them with increasing complexity. I also Increased the first (Example) test case from 3 to 4 to make it obvious that neither input or output are sorted in any manner.
Yeah capitalized name can be ignored for this problem.
Names are specified as capitalized to reassure the solvers that no name can include the lower case phrase "passes the ball".

Wrongly dealing with name fields is a common problem for people who have non-ascii characters in their name. Special characters in names are common and should be understood by any software dealing with people. Other than Little Bobby Tables, all names in the "Weird characters" test case are real names that people use.

Made the text bold, thanks!

I just got this Clash and solved it in python. I passed all tests except the "Weird characters" one. My code appears to be pretty identical to yours (except without all the assert). Furthermore, the output appears to be correct, but for some reason Codingame doesn't recognise it. This is pretty frustrating as it seems to be a problem with Codingame rather than with my code.

I get this self-contradicting output for the "Weird characters" test. It seems that I correctly outputted the expected output, but for some reason Codingame then decides that I outputted nothing.

Standard Output Stream:

André 3000 passes the ball to Conan O'Brian
John F. Kennedy Jr. passes the ball to André 3000
X Æ A-12 Musk passes the ball to Robert'); DROP TABLE Students;--
Conan O'Brian passes the ball to X Æ A-12 Musk
Robert'); DROP TABLE Students;-- passes the ball to John F. Kennedy Jr.

Failure
Found:
Nothing

Expected:
André 3000 passes the ball to Conan O'Brian

I also tried to copy-paste YOUR code, from the "Solution" at the bottom of this contribution page, in the IDE, and it gets the same error. Today even your solution is not a solution.

So, right now, the "Weird characters" test seems to be impossible to solve.
